case_vignette: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While performing the remainder of the physical examination the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

I've been feeling nauseous and have a headache, and I've thrown up a couple of times.

[Answer received: Female, 45 years old]

Final Diagnosis: Migraine with vomiting.

trial_1.summarized_mcq: Subarachnoidal hemorrhage. Nausea, headache, and vomiting are common symptoms of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the sudden onset of repeated vomiting can be a sign of this condition. Other symptoms may include a severe headache that is worse with eye movement or straining, sensitivity to light, and a stiff neck. Subarachnoid hemorrhages are caused by bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the space between the arachnoid and pia mater membranes surrounding the brain. This type of hemorrhage is often caused by a ruptured aneurysm. Ischemic stroke, subdural hematoma, and epidural hematoma may also cause similar symptoms, but their presentations can vary. For example, ischemic stroke may cause weakness or paralysis on one side of the body, while subdural hematomas and epidural hematomas may cause gradual onset of symptoms and may be associated with head trauma.
trial_1.summarized_frq:
Migraine with vomiting or Migraine syndrome with vomiting
or
Vestibular Migraine
or
Motion Sickness
or
Gastroenteritis
or
Meniere's disease

Note: A definitive diagnosis cannot be made based on the given symptoms alone. Further evaluation and tests are required to confirm the diagnosis.
